text.section: A statutory trust is a legal entity distinct from its trustees and beneficial owners.
A statutory trust may hold or take title to property in its own name, or in the name of a trustee in the trusteeâ€™s capacity as trustee, whether in an active, passive, or custodial capacity.

Property transferred to or otherwise acquired by a statutory trust shall be the property of the trust and not of the beneficial owners or of the trustees. A creditor of a beneficial owner or trustee may not obtain possession of, or otherwise exercise legal or equitable remedies with respect to, the property of a statutory trust or the property of or associated with any series thereof.
The property of a statutory trust is not subject to KRS 381.135(1)(a)1.

law.history: Created 2012 Ky. Acts ch. 81, sec. 17, effective July 12, 2012.
